body: So if I understand the writer code correctly, `createWriter` is called per `DoFn` instance, e.g. creating one connection per CPU per worker, and then doing blocking `mapper.save(entity)` per element?

Changes Unknown when pulling **d2b384a20dbb0213d0f63e74713a06d63bad8d39 on kennknowles:ReduceFnRunner** into ** on apache:master**.

OK, I looked through the PR but I was taking notes in a text file :) Before I start nitpicking on code in detail, a bunch of high level comments:

* Overall, this looks like a reasonable compromise and I don't have ideas on how to make this much better - unless you want to resurrect the discussion and try to come up with such ideas :) In particular, if we had unlimited time for design, I'd like to see the following. Perhaps that's like Beam-3.0 stuff, but anyway.
** It'd be cool if we could achieve more unification between wrapper transforms like AvroIO vs. TextIO vs. XmlIO vs. TFRecordIO (i.e. not duplicate much code when adding dynamic-destinations support to all of them) but that's topic for another PR.
** It'd be cool to have even more dynamicity, e.g. have an AvroIO.Write that can use different schemas for different destinations, as I suggested on the beam-dev thread https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/40f123534f452fe85e74f9cf2d1a7d043f52aa1f2920e311612ac074@%3Cdev.beam.apache.org%3E .
* WriteFiles seems to now unconditionally GBK all the data. Should we have a "fast path" for the common case, when writing unwindowed data to a single destination?
* Test coverage for the new code seems mainly represented by a new TextIO test with dynamic destinations. I think there needs to be more explicit coverage for the new code in WriteFiles and FileBasedSink, and a dynamic destinations AvroIO test. Maybe run unit tests with coverage also - I think we should see near-100% coverage in these classes (FileBasedSink, WriteFiles) from running only their own unit tests.

Ready for review.

+R: @lukecwik @aaltay
Run Dataflow ValidatesRunner
